# Event-driven development

## Contents
- Spring Boot Modulith
  - ApplicationModuleListener
  - Internalize/Externalize events
- Pulsar

## Spring Boot Modulith

### ApplicationEventPublisher
Use `ApplicationEventPublisher` to abstract the event creation.
```java
private final ApplicationEventPublisher eventPublisher;

@Transactional
public Order createNewOrder(Order newOrder) {
        LOGGER.debug("Start of OrderManagement complete function");
        // Order creation logic here
        // ...

        Order order = new Order.Builder()
        .id(newOrder.getId())
        .owner(newOrder.getOwner())
        .amount(newOrder.getAmount())
        .creationDatetime(Instant.now())
        .build();
        order = orderRepository.save(order);

        // Publish the OrderCreationEvent
        eventPublisher.publishEvent(new OrderCreationEvent(this, order));
        LOGGER.debug("End of OrderManagement complete function");
        return order;
        }
```

To save event, enable this option: `spring.modulith.republish-outstanding-events-on-restart=true` <br/>
The app will resend unfinished event when it restarts.

To save event in a database, use this option: `spring.modulith.events.jdbc-schema-initialization.enabled=true`<br/>

<div style="text-align: center;">

![schema](data:image/png;base64,)

</div>

### ApplicationModuleListener
Use `@ApplicationModuleListener` to catch specific event and perform any action.

```java
@ApplicationModuleListener
public void onOrderCreationEvent (OrderCreationEvent event) throws InterruptedException {
    LOGGER.info("New order created: {}", event.getOrder());

    // other logic
    Thread.sleep(15_000);

    // Send event to Kafka/Pulsar/MQTT/...
    stringTemplate.send(STRING_TOPIC, event);
}
```

You can use `@Transactional` on the upper layer to ensure the transactional.
